Rule Name: BB:Threats: Port Scans: UDP Port Scan

Rule Name: BB:Threats: Scanning: Empty Responsive Flows High
Tests:
and when the IP protocol is one of the following TCP
and when the source packets is greater than 100000
and when the source byte/packet ratio is less than 65 bytes/packet
and when the destination byte/packet ratio is less than 65 bytes/packet
and when the source bytes is greater than 1
and when the destination bytes is greater than 1
Notes: This BB detects potential reconnaissance activity where the source packet count is greater than 100,000.
Not Used Tests:
and when the IP protocol is one of the following TCP
and when the source packets is greater than 100000
and when the source byte/packet ratio is less than 65 bytes/packet
and when the destination byte/packet ratio is less than 65 bytes/packet
and when the source bytes is greater than 1
and when the destination bytes is greater than 1

Rule Name: BB:Threats: Scanning: Empty Responsive Flows Low
Tests:
and when the IP protocol is one of the following TCP
and when the source packets is greater than 500
and when the source byte/packet ratio is less than 65 bytes/packet
and when the destination byte/packet ratio is less than 65 bytes/packet
and when the source bytes is greater than 1
and when the destination bytes is greater than 1
Notes: This BB detects potential reconnaissance activity where the source packet count is greater than 500.
Used by Building Blocks: BB:CategoryDefinition: Recon Flows

Rule Name: BB:Threats: Scanning: Empty Responsive Flows Medium
Tests:
and when the IP protocol is one of the following TCP
and when the source packets is greater than 5000
and when the source byte/packet ratio is less than 65 bytes/packet
and when the destination byte/packet ratio is less than 65 bytes/packet
and when the destination bytes is greater than 1
and when the source bytes is greater than 1
Notes: This BB detects potential reconnaissance activity where the source packet count is greater than 5,000.
Used by Building Blocks: BB:CategoryDefinition: Recon Flows

Tests:
and when the source TCP flags are any of SR, SF, FUP, FUPSAR78, SRAFU

Notes: This Building Block identifies flows that have an illegal TCP flag combination.

Rule Name: BB:Threats: Suspicious IP Protocol Usage: Large DNS Packets
Tests:
and when the destination byte/packet ratio is greater than 1000 bytes/packet
and when the destination port is one of the following 53
and when the flow context is Local to Remote, Remote to Local
and when the destination bytes is greater than 1
Notes: This Building Block identifies flows with abnormaly large DNS packets
FlowContext:
Local to Remote
Remote to Local
Used by Building Blocks: BB:CategoryDefinition: Suspicious Flows

Rule Name: BB:Threats: Suspicious IP Protocol Usage: Large ICMP Packets
Tests:
and when the IP protocol is one of the following ICMP
and when the flow duration is greater than 10 minutes
and when the source byte/packet ratio is greater than 1000 bytes/packet
and when the source bytes is greater than 1
Notes: This Building Block identifies flows with abnormaly large ICMP packets
Used by Building Blocks: BB:CategoryDefinition: Suspicious Flows

Rule Name: BB:Threats: Suspicious IP Protocol Usage: Long Duration Outbound Flow
Tests:
and when the flow context is Local to Remote
and when the flow duration is greater than 48 hours
Notes: This Building Block identifies flows that have been active for more than 48 hours
Used by Building Blocks: BB:CategoryDefinition: Suspicious Flows

Rule Name: BB:Threats: Suspicious IP Protocol Usage: Suspicious ICMP Type Code

and NOT when the ICMP type is any of Echo Reply, Echo, Destination Unreachable, Time Exceeded

Echo

Time Exceeded

Rule Name: BB:Threats: Suspicious IP Protocol Usage: Unidirectional ICMP Flows
Tests:
and when the IP protocol is one of the following ICMP
and when a flow matches any of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Unidirectional Flow
Notes: This Building Block identifies unidirectional ICMP flows.
UsingBB: BB:CategoryDefinition: Unidirectional Flow
FlowType: BB:CategoryDefinition: Unidirectional Flow
Used by Building Blocks: BB:CategoryDefinition: Suspicious Flows

Rule Name: BB:Threats: Suspicious IP Protocol Usage: Unidirectional ICMP Replys
Tests:
and when the IP protocol is one of the following ICMP
and when the ICMP type is any of Echo Reply, Destination Unreachable, Timestamp Reply, Information Reply, Address Mask Reply, Mobile Registration Reply, Domain Name Reply
and when a flow matches any of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Unidirectional Flow
Notes: This Building Block identifies traffic where ICMP replies are seen with no request.
UsingBB: BB:CategoryDefinition: Unidirectional Flow
FlowType: BB:CategoryDefinition: Unidirectional Flow
ICMPType:
Echo Reply
Destination Unreachable
Timestamp Reply
Information Reply
Address Mask Reply
Mobile Registration Reply
Domain Name Reply
Used by Building Blocks: BB:CategoryDefinition: Suspicious Flows

Rule Name: BB:Threats: Suspicious IP Protocol Usage: Zero Payload Bidirectional Flows
Tests:
and when the source byte/packet ratio is less than 65 bytes/packet
and when the destination byte/packet ratio is less than 65 bytes/packet
and when the source/destination packet ratio is equal to 1
Notes: This Building Block identifies bidirectional traffic that doesn't include payload.
Used by Building Blocks: BB:CategoryDefinition: Suspicious Flows

Rule Name: BB:Threats: Suspicious IP Protocol Usage:Unidirectional TCP Flows
Tests:
and when the IP protocol is one of the following TCP
and when a flow matches any of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Unidirectional Flow
Notes: This Building Block identifies unidirectional TCP flows.
UsingBB: BB:CategoryDefinition: Unidirectional Flow
FlowType: BB:CategoryDefinition: Unidirectional Flow
Used by Building Blocks: BB:CategoryDefinition: Suspicious Flows

Rule Name: BB:Threats: Suspicious IP Protocol Usage:Unidirectional UDP and Misc Flows
Tests:
and when the IP protocol is one of the following UDP, other, Uncommon
and when a flow matches any of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Unidirectional Flow
Notes: This Building Block identifies unidirectional UDP and other miscellaneous flows.
UsingBB: BB:CategoryDefinition: Unidirectional Flow
FlowType: BB:CategoryDefinition: Unidirectional Flow
Used by Building Blocks:
BB:Suspicious: Remote: Unidirectional UDP or Misc Flows
BB:CategoryDefinition: Suspicious Flows

Rule Name: BB:UBA : Authentication User or Group or Policy Added
Tests: and when the event category for the event is one of the following Authentication.Computer Account Added, Authentication.Group Added, Authentication.Policy Added, Authentication.User Account Added
Notes: This building block detects account, group, or policy additions.
EventCategory:
Authentication.Computer Account Added
Authentication.Group Added
Authentication.Policy Added
Authentication.User Account Added
Not Used Tests: and when the event category for the event is one of the following Authentication.Computer Account Added, Authentication.Group Added, Authentication.Policy Added, Authentication.User Account Added

Rule Name: BB:UBA : Authentication User or Group or Policy Changed
Tests:
and when the event category for the event is one of the following Authentication.Computer Account Changed, Authentication.Group Changed, Authentication.Group Member
 Added, Authentication.Group Member Removed, Authentication.Password Change Succeeded, Authentication.Policy Change, Authentication.User Account Changed, Aut
hentication.User Right Assigned, Authentication.User Right Removed
Notes: This building block detects account or group changes.
EventCategory:
Authentication.Computer Account Changed
Authentication.Group Changed
Authentication.Group Member
Not Used Tests:
and when the event category for the event is one of the following Authentication.Computer Account Changed, Authentication.Group Changed, Authentication.Group Member
 Added, Authentication.Group Member Removed, Authentication.Password Change Succeeded, Authentication.Policy Change, Authentication.User Account Changed, Aut
hentication.User Right Assigned, Authentication.User Right Removed

Tests:
and NOT when the event matches Username is N/A
and NOT when the event(s) were detected by one or more of IBM Sense, Health Metrics, SIM Audit, System Notification
and NOT when the event(s) were detected by one or more of 100727
Notes:
Modify this building block to EXCLUDE :

        - events which do NOT include Username information

        - log source types which do NOT include Username information OR which do NOT apply to your risk analysis goals.
            Note - This includes the "IBM Sense" event source type, as reprocessing its own output could lead to unpredictable results.

        - log source groups which do NOT apply to your risk analysis goals.
            Note - IBM has populated this rule with a test to allow event sources placed in "UBA : Trusted Log Source Group" to bypass UBA analysis. This log source group is empty by default.
NotLogSource:
IBM Sense
Health Metrics
SIM Audit
System Notification

Tests:
and when the event(s) were detected by one or more of IBM DNS Analyzer
and when an event matches any of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
Notes: Building block for common tests for all DNS App related rules. Maps to IBM DNS Analyzer DSM and other UBA common filters.
UsingBB: BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
Used by Use Cases:
UBA : Potential Access to DGA Domain
UBA : Potential Access to Tunneling Domain
UBA : Potential Access to Squatting Domain

Tests: and when any of Source or Destination IP are contained in any of UBA : IOCs-Locky IP - IP
Notes: This building block looks for IP addresses in the UBA : IOCs-Locky IP reference set. Any known IP addresses related to Locky Ransomware should be added to this table.
Not Used Tests: and when any of Source or Destination IP are contained in any of UBA : IOCs-Locky IP - IP

Tests: and when any of URL (custom) are contained in any of UBA : IOCs-Locky URL - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Notes: This building block looks for URLs in the UBA : IOCs-Locky URL reference set. Any known URL related to Locky Ransomware should be added to this table.
Not Used Tests: and when any of URL (custom) are contained in any of UBA : IOCs-Locky URL - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)

Tests: and when any of SHA256 Hash (custom), SHA1 Hash (custom), MD5 Hash (custom), File Hash (custom), IMP Hash (custom), Root Hash (custom) are contained in any of UBA : Malware Activity WannaCry - Hash - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Notes: This building block looks for hashes in the UBA : Malware Activity WannaCry - Hash reference set. Any known hashes related to WannaCry should be added to this table.
Not Used Tests: and when any of SHA256 Hash (custom), SHA1 Hash (custom), MD5 Hash (custom), File Hash (custom), IMP Hash (custom), Root Hash (custom) are contained in any of UBA : Malware Activity WannaCry - Hash - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)

Tests: and when any of Source IP, Destination IP are contained in any of UBA : Malware Activity WannaCry - IP's - IP
Notes: This building block looks for IP addresses in the UBA : Malware Activity WannaCry - IP reference set. Any known IP addresses related to WannaCry should be added to this table.
SourceOrDestinationIP: UBA : Malware Activity WannaCry - IP's - IP
Not Used Tests: and when any of Source IP, Destination IP are contained in any of UBA : Malware Activity WannaCry - IP's - IP

Tests: and when any of URL (custom) are contained in any of UBA : Malware Activity WannaCry - URL's - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Notes: This building block looks for URLs in the UBA : Malware Activity WannaCry - URL reference set. Any known URL related to WannaCry should be added to this table.
Not Used Tests: and when any of URL (custom) are contained in any of UBA : Malware Activity WannaCry - URL's - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)

Tests: and when at least 10 events are seen with the same Source IP and different Username in 1 minutes
Notes: This rule detects horizontal authentication failure brute force attack by looking at large number of authentication failure events in a small time frame with multiple distinct user accounts being targeted from the same origin.
EventAtLeastSeen: with the same Source IP and different Username in 1 minutes
Not Used Tests: and when at least 10 events are seen with the same Source IP and different Username in 1 minutes

Tests: and when at least 100 events are seen with the same Username in 1 minutes
Notes: This rule detects large number of authentication failure events against a single user in a shorter time frame. This rule detects vertical brute force attack.
EventAtLeastSeen: with the same Username in 1 minutes
Not Used Tests: and when at least 100 events are seen with the same Username in 1 minutes

Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
and when an event matches all of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and when all of Username are contained in any of UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Observed - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
and NOT when all of Username are contained in any of UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Recent - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Notes: Indicates that a user successfully logged in after a period of inactivity.

BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
Not Used Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
and when an event matches all of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and when all of Username are contained in any of UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Observed - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
and NOT when all of Username are contained in any of UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Recent - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)

Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
and when an event matches all of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and when all of Username are contained in all of UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Observed - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case), UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Dormant - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Notes: Indicates that subsequent, successful user logins occurred between a period of inactivity and the time-to-live of the account entry in "UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Dormant" expires.
UsingBB:
BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
Not Used Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
and when an event matches all of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and when all of Username are contained in all of UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Observed - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case), UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Dormant - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)

Rule Name: BB:UBA : Privileged User, First Time Privilege Use (logic)
Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following BB:UBA : Privileged Activity
and when an event matches all of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and NOT when all of Username are contained in any of UBA : User Accounts, Privileged, Observed - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Notes: Indicates when a user is first observed in privileged activities for the first time. Consider disabling the reporting rule, "UBA : First Privilege Escalation", for a cycle of operational time to allow the reference set "UBA : Accounts, Privileged, Observed" to populate. This helps to reduce the load of events that need attention while the system is baselining normal activity.
UsingBB:
BB:UBA : Privileged Activity
BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
Not Used Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following BB:UBA : Privileged Activity
and when an event matches all of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and NOT when all of Username are contained in any of UBA : User Accounts, Privileged, Observed - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)

Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
and when an event matches all of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and NOT when all of Username are contained in any of UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Observed - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Notes: Indicates that a user was successfully logged in for the first time. Consider disabling the reporting rule [UBA : User First Time Login,  Report] for a cycle of operational time to allow the reference set [UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Observed] to populate. Temporarily disabling the rule helps to reduce the load of events that need attention while the system baselines normal activity.
UsingBB:
BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
Not Used Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
and when an event matches all of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and NOT when all of Username are contained in any of UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Observed - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)

Tests:
and when an event matches any of the following BB:Hanzo: SCSP Registry Creation_Modification_Deletion
and when the Event Payload contains \HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Image File Execution Options
Notes: Windows contains accessibility features that may be launched with a key combination before a user has logged in (for example, when the user is on the Windows logon screen). An adversary can modify the way these programs are launched to get a command prompt or backdoor without logging in to the system.
UsingBB: BB:Hanzo: SCSP Registry Creation_Modification_Deletion
Not Used Tests:

Rule Name: Anomaly: Excessive Firewall Accepts Across Multiple Hosts
Tests:
and NOT when an event matches any of the following BB:HostDefinition: Servers
and when any of these BB:CategoryDefinition: Firewall or ACL Accept, BB:DeviceDefinition: FW / Router / Switch with the same source IP more than 100 times, across more than 100 destination IP within 5 minutes
Notes: Reports excessive Firewall Accepts across multiple hosts.  More than 100 events were detected across at least 100 unique destination IP addresses in 5 minutes.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: Excessive Firewall Accepts Across Multiple Hosts
UsingBB:
BB:HostDefinition: Servers
BB:CategoryDefinition: Firewall or ACL Accept
BB:DeviceDefinition: FW / Router / Switch with the same source IP more than 100 times
NotEventType: BB:HostDefinition: Servers
Not Used Tests:
and NOT when an event matches any of the following BB:HostDefinition: Servers
and when any of these BB:CategoryDefinition: Firewall or ACL Accept, BB:DeviceDefinition: FW / Router / Switch with the same source IP more than 100 times, across more than 100 destination IP within 5 minutes

Rule Name: AssetExclusion: Exclude DNS Name By IP

and NOT when any of Identity Host Name are contained in any of Asset Reconciliation DNS Whitelist - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case), Asset Reconciliation DNS Blacklist - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)

Notes: Blacklists a DNS Name that has been associated with N different IPs over a given period of time.

within 1 hours

Tests:
and where the offense severity is greater than 5
and where the offense Credibility is greater than 5
and where the offense Relevance is greater than 5
Notes: Reports any offense matching the severity, credibility, relevance minimums to e-mail. You must configure the e-mail address. You can limit the number of e-mails sent by tuning the severity, credibility, and relevance limits. Also, this rule only sends one e-mail every hour, per offense.
Not Used Tests:
and where the offense severity is greater than 5
and where the offense Credibility is greater than 5
and where the offense Relevance is greater than 5

Tests:
and where the offense severity is greater than 5
and where the offense Credibility is greater than 5
and where the offense Relevance is greater than 5
Notes: Reports any offense matching the severity, credibility, or relevance minimums to syslog.
Not Used Tests:
and where the offense severity is greater than 5
and where the offense Credibility is greater than 5
and where the offense Relevance is greater than 5

Tests: and when the local destination host exists Either Actively or Passively seen
Notes: Adjusts the relevance and credibility of flows and events where the destination is a local asset.
Not Used Tests: and when the local destination host exists Either Actively or Passively seen

Tests: and when the local destination host destination port is open Either Actively or Passively seen
Notes: Adjusts the relevance and credibility of events and flows when the destination port is known to be active.
Not Used Tests: and when the local destination host destination port is open Either Actively or Passively seen

Tests: and NOT when the destination asset has a weight greater than 6
Notes: Adjusts the relevance of events and flows if the destination asset weight is high.
Not Used Tests: and NOT when the destination asset has a weight greater than 6

Tests: and NOT when the destination asset has a weight less than 4
Notes: Adjusts the relevance of events and flows if the destination asset weight is low.
Not Used Tests: and NOT when the destination asset has a weight less than 4

Tests:
and NOT when the destination asset has a weight less than 7
and NOT when the destination asset has a weight greater than 3
Notes: Adjusts the relevance of events and flows if the destination asset weight is medium.
Not Used Tests:
and NOT when the destination asset has a weight less than 7
and NOT when the destination asset has a weight greater than 3

Tests:
and when the event category for the event is one of the following Exploit, Potential Exploit
and when the event context is Local to Local, Remote to Local
and when the destination is vulnerable to current exploit on current port
Notes: Rule detects an attack against a vulnerable local destination, where the host is known to exist, and the host is vulnerable to the attack.
EventCategory:
Exploit
Potential Exploit
EventContext:
Local to Local
Remote to Local
Destination: vulnerable to current exploit on current port
Used by Use Cases: Destination Vulnerable to Detected Exploit on a Different Port

Rule Name: Destination Vulnerable to Detected Exploit on a Different Port
Tests:
and when the event category for the event is one of the following Exploit, Potential Exploit
and when the event context is Local to Local, Remote to Local
and when the destination is vulnerable to current exploit on any port
and NOT when an event matches any of the following Destination Vulnerable to Detected Exploit
Notes: Reports an attack against a vulnerable local destination host, where the host is known to exist, and the host is vulnerable to the attack on a different port.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: Destination Vulnerable to Detected Exploit on a Different Port
EventCategory:
Exploit
Potential Exploit
NotEventType: Destination Vulnerable to Detected Exploit
EventContext:
Local to Local
Remote to Local
Destination: vulnerable to current exploit on any port
Not Used Tests:
and when the event category for the event is one of the following Exploit, Potential Exploit
and when the event context is Local to Local, Remote to Local
and when the destination is vulnerable to current exploit on any port
and NOT when an event matches any of the following Destination Vulnerable to Detected Exploit

Rule Name: Destination Vulnerable to Different Exploit than Attempted on Targeted Port
Tests:
and where the Event Category for the event is one of the following Exploit, Potential Exploit
and where the attack context is Local to Local, Remote to Local
and where the target is vulnerable to any exploit on current port
and NOT when we see an event match any of the following Exploit: Target Vulnerable to Detected Exploit
Notes: Reports an attack against a vulnerable local destination host, where the host is known to exist, and the host is vulnerable to some attack but not the one being attempted.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: Destination Vulnerable to a Different Attack than Attempted
NotEventType: Exploit: Target Vulnerable to Detected Exploit
AttackContext:
Local to Local
Remote to Local
Not Used Tests:
and where the Event Category for the event is one of the following Exploit, Potential Exploit
and where the attack context is Local to Local, Remote to Local
and where the target is vulnerable to any exploit on current port
and NOT when we see an event match any of the following Exploit: Target Vulnerable to Detected Exploit

Tests: and when the event(s) have not been detected by one or more of Flow Classification Engine-5 :: vm175 for 3600 seconds

Not Used Tests: and when the event(s) have not been detected by one or more of Flow Classification Engine-5 :: vm175 for 3600 seconds

Tests: and when any of these BB:DeviceDefinition: Devices to Monitor for High Event Rates with the same log source more than 500 times, across more than 0 destination IP within 1 minutes

UsingBB: BB:DeviceDefinition: Devices to Monitor for High Event Rates with the same log source more than 500 times
Not Used Tests: and when any of these BB:DeviceDefinition: Devices to Monitor for High Event Rates with the same log source more than 500 times, across more than 0 destination IP within 1 minutes

Port Scan, NMAP (Recon)
Reports excessive firewall denies from a single host. Detects more than 400 firewall deny attempts from a single source to a single destination within 5 minutes.

BB:CategoryDefinition: Firewall or ACL Denies with the same source IP more than 400 times

and when any of these BB:CategoryDefinition: Firewall or ACL Denies with the same source IP more than 400 times, across exactly 1 destination IP within 5 minutes

Rule Name: First-Time User Access to Critical Asset
Tests:
and when an event matches any of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
and when any of Destination IP are contained in any of Critical Assets - IP
and NOT when any of Username is the key and any of Destination IP is the value in any of User-System Authentication or Usage - IP
and when the event username matches the following [^\w\d]*
Notes: Before enabling this rule, add systems to be monitored to the Critical Assets reference set. To make use of it, enable it for a 'learning' period of time such that the User-System Authentication or Usage reference collection will establish normal access patterns. After this period, edit the rule response to "Ensure the dispatched event is part of an offense" and make sure that the offense will be indexed on Username.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: First-Time User Access to Critical Asset
UsingBB: BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
Not Used Tests:
and when an event matches any of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
and when any of Destination IP are contained in any of Critical Assets - IP
and NOT when any of Username is the key and any of Destination IP is the value in any of User-System Authentication or Usage - IP
and when the event username matches the following [^\w\d]*

Tests: and when an event matches any of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Key Loggers
Notes:
To detect Key Loggers. 
Adversaries can use methods of capturing user input for obtaining credentials for Valid Accounts and information Collection that include keylogging and user input field interception.
Keylogging is the most prevalent type of input capture, with many different ways of intercepting keystrokes, but other methods exist to target information for specific purposes, such as performing a UAC prompt or wrapping the Windows default credential provider. 
Keylogging is likely to be used to acquire credentials for new access opportunities when Credential Dumping efforts are not effective, and may require an adversary to remain passive on a system for a period of time before an opportunity arises.
Adversaries may also install code on externally facing portals, such as a VPN login page, to capture and transmit credentials of users who attempt to log into the service. This variation on input capture may be conducted post-compromise using legitimate administrative access as a backup measure to maintain network access through External Remote Services and Valid Accounts or as part of the initial compromise by exploitation of the externally facing web service.
UsingBB: BB:CategoryDefinition: Key Loggers
Not Used Tests: and when an event matches any of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Key Loggers

Rule Name: Large Outbound Transfer High Rate of Transfer
Tests:
and when the source bytes is greater than 200000
and when the flow context is Local to Remote
and when the flow bias is any of the following mostly outbound
and when at least 10 flows are seen with the same Source IP, Destination Port, Destination IP in 12 minutes
Notes: Detects a single host that is sending more data out of the network than received.  This rule detects over 2 MB of data transferred over a 12 minute period.

FlowBias: any of the following mostly outbound

Tests:
and when the flow bias is any of the following outbound
and when the source packet rate is greater than 1000 packets/second
and when the IP protocol is one of the following TCP

Rule Name: Local L2L Suspicious Probe Events Detected
Tests:
and NOT when an event matches any of the following BB:HostDefinition: Servers
and when the event context is Local to Local, Local to Remote
and when any of these BB:CategoryDefinition: Recon Events, BB:CategoryDefinition: Suspicious Events with the same source IP more than 20 times, across more than 5 destination IP within 4 minutes
Notes: Reports when various suspicious or reconnaissance events have been detected from the same local source IP address to more than 5 destination IP address in 4 minutes. This can indicate various forms of host probing, such as Nmap reconnaissance, which attempts to identify the services and operation systems of the target.
UsingBB:
BB:HostDefinition: Servers
BB:CategoryDefinition: Recon Events
BB:CategoryDefinition: Suspicious Events with the same source IP more than 20 times
NotEventType: BB:HostDefinition: Servers
EventContext:
Local to Local
Local to Remote
Not Used Tests:
and NOT when an event matches any of the following BB:HostDefinition: Servers
and when the event context is Local to Local, Local to Remote
and when any of these BB:CategoryDefinition: Recon Events, BB:CategoryDefinition: Suspicious Events with the same source IP more than 20 times, across more than 5 destination IP within 4 minutes

Tests:
and NOT when an event matches any of the following BB:HostDefinition: Mail Servers, BB:HostReference: Mail Servers
and when the event(s) were detected by one or more of Flow Classification Engine
and when any of these BB:CategoryDefinition: Mail Policy Violation with the same source IP more than 20 times, across more than 1 destination IP within 1 minutes
and when the event context is Local to Remote
Notes: Reports a local host sending more than 20 SMTP flows in 1 minute. This may indicate a host being used as a spam relay or infected with a form of mass mailing worm.
UsingBB:
BB:HostDefinition: Mail Servers
BB:HostReference: Mail Servers
BB:CategoryDefinition: Mail Policy Violation with the same source IP more than 20 times
NotEventMatches:
BB:HostDefinition: Mail Servers
BB:HostReference: Mail Servers
NotEventType:
BB:HostDefinition: Mail Servers
BB:HostReference: Mail Servers
EventContext: Local to Remote
Not Used Tests:
and NOT when an event matches any of the following BB:HostDefinition: Mail Servers, BB:HostReference: Mail Servers
and when the event(s) were detected by one or more of Flow Classification Engine
and when any of these BB:CategoryDefinition: Mail Policy Violation with the same source IP more than 20 times, across more than 1 destination IP within 1 minutes
and when the event context is Local to Remote

Tests:
and NOT when the flow context is Local to Local
and when a flow matches any of the following BB:Policy Violation: Compliance Policy Violation: Clear Text Application Usage
and when a flow matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Successful Communication
Notes: Detects flows to or from the Internet where the application type uses clear text passwords.  This may include applications such as Telnet, FTP, etc.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: Policy: Local: Clear Text Application Usage
UsingBB:
BB:Policy Violation: Compliance Policy Violation: Clear Text Application Usage
BB:CategoryDefinition: Successful Communication
FlowType: BB:Policy Violation: Compliance Policy Violation: Clear Text Application Usage
Not Used Tests:
and NOT when the flow context is Local to Local
and when a flow matches any of the following BB:Policy Violation: Compliance Policy Violation: Clear Text Application Usage
and when a flow matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Successful Communication

Tests:
and when the flow context is Local to Local
and when the flow matches Application is DataTransfer.FTP
and NOT when the destination port is one of the following 21, 20
and when a flow matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Successful Communication
Notes: Detects a local FTP server on a non-standard port.  The default port for FTP is TCP port 21.  Detecting FTP on other ports may indicate an exploited host, where the attacker has installed this server to provide backdoor access to the host.
UsingBB: BB:CategoryDefinition: Successful Communication
FlowType: DataTransfer.FTP
Not Used Tests:
and when the flow context is Local to Local
and when the flow matches Application is DataTransfer.FTP
and NOT when the destination port is one of the following 21, 20
and when a flow matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Successful Communication

Rule Name: Local: SSH or Telnet Detected on Non-Standard Port
Tests:
and NOT when the flow context is Local to Local
and when the flow matches Application is any of [RemoteAccess.Telnet or RemoteAccess.SSH]
and NOT when the destination port is one of the following 22, 23
and when a flow matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Successful Communication
Notes: Detects an SSH or Telnet server on a non-standard port.  The default port for SSH and Telnet servers is TCP port 22 and 23.  Detecting SSH or Telnet operating on other ports may indicate an exploited host, where the attacker has installed these servers to provide backdoor access to the host.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: SSH or Telnet Detected on Non-Standard Port
UsingBB: BB:CategoryDefinition: Successful Communication
FlowType: any of [RemoteAccess.Telnet or RemoteAccess.SSH]
Not Used Tests:
and NOT when the flow context is Local to Local
and when the flow matches Application is any of [RemoteAccess.Telnet or RemoteAccess.SSH]
and NOT when the destination port is one of the following 22, 23
and when a flow matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Successful Communication

Rule Name: Login Failures Followed By Success from the same Source IP
Tests: and when BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success match at least 1 times in 5 minutes after any of Multiple Login Failures from the Same Source (old) match with the same Source IP
Notes: Reports multiple log in failures to a single host, followed by a successful log in to the host.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: Login Failures Followed By Success from the same Source IP

Not Used Tests: and when BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success match at least 1 times in 5 minutes after any of Multiple Login Failures from the Same Source (old) match with the same Source IP

Tests: and when an event matches any of the following BB:Hanzo: Activities on Windows SID History
Notes:
Detection of SID History Injection.
The Windows security identifier (SID) is a unique value that identifies a user or group account. SIDs are used by Windows security in both security descriptors and access tokens. An account can hold additional SIDs in the SID-History Active Directory attribute, allowing inter-operable account migration between domains (e.g., all values in SID-History are included in access tokens).
Adversaries may use this mechanism for privilege escalation. With Domain Administrator (or equivalent) rights, harvested or well-known SID values may be inserted into SID-History to enable impersonation of arbitrary users/groups such as Enterprise Administrators. This manipulation may result in elevated access to local resources and/or access to otherwise inaccessible domains via lateral movement techniques such as Remote Services, Windows Admin Shares, or Windows Remote Management.
UsingBB: BB:Hanzo: Activities on Windows SID History
EventMatches: BB:Hanzo: Activities on Windows SID History
EventType: BB:Hanzo: Activities on Windows SID History
Not Used Tests: and when an event matches any of the following BB:Hanzo: Activities on Windows SID History

Rule Name: Source Address is a Bogon IP
Tests:
and when the source IP is a part of any of the following Bogon
and when the source is Remote
Notes: Adjusts the severity of events and flows when the source IP is a known bogon address.  Traffic from known bogon addresses may indicate the possibility of the source IP address being spoofed.
Not Used Tests:
and when the source IP is a part of any of the following Bogon
and when the source is Remote

Rule Name: Source Address is a Known Questionable IP
Tests: and when the source IP is a part of any of the following HostileNets
Notes: Adjusts the severity of events and flows when the source IP is a known questionable host.
Not Used Tests: and when the source IP is a part of any of the following HostileNets

Tests: and when the local source host exists Either Actively or Passively seen
Notes: Adjusts the relevance and credibility of flows and events where the source is a local asset.
Not Used Tests: and when the local source host exists Either Actively or Passively seen

Tests: and NOT when the source asset has a weight greater than 6
Notes: Adjusts the relevance of events and flows if the source asset weight is high.
Not Used Tests: and NOT when the source asset has a weight greater than 6

Tests: and NOT when the source asset has a weight less than 4
Notes: Adjusts the relevance of events and flows if the source asset weight is low.
Not Used Tests: and NOT when the source asset has a weight less than 4

Tests:
and NOT when the source asset has a weight less than 7
and NOT when the source asset has a weight greater than 3
Notes: Adjusts the relevance of events and flows if the source asset weight is medium.
Not Used Tests:
and NOT when the source asset has a weight less than 7
and NOT when the source asset has a weight greater than 3

Rule Name: UBA : Account or Group or Privileges Added
Tests: and when an event matches all of the following UBA : Common Event Filters, BB:UBA : Authentication User or Group or Policy Added
Notes:
This event detects when a user performs an action that adds a user account or group or policy and dispatches an IBM Sense event to increment the originating user's risk score.

    Clients wishing to tune the impact of this rule on users' overall risk scores may consider modifying the building block rule "BB:UBA : Authentication User or Group or Policy Added" by adding event categories of interest to their organization.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: UBA : Account or Group or Privileges Added
UsingBB: BB:UBA : Authentication User or Group or Policy Added
EventType:
UBA : Common Event Filters
BB:UBA : Authentication User or Group or Policy Added
Not Used Tests: and when an event matches all of the following UBA : Common Event Filters, BB:UBA : Authentication User or Group or Policy Added

Rule Name: UBA : Account or Group or Privileges Modified
Tests: and when an event matches all of the following UBA : Common Event Filters, BB:UBA : Authentication User or Group or Policy Changed
Notes:
This event detects when a user performs an action that modifies a user account or group or policy and dispatches an IBM Sense event to increment the originating user's risk score.

    Clients wishing to tune the impact of this rule on users' overall risk scores may consider modifying the building block rule "BB:UBA : Authentication User or Group or Policy Changed" by adding event categories of interest to their organization.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: UBA : Account or Group or Privileges Modified
UsingBB: BB:UBA : Authentication User or Group or Policy Changed
EventType:
UBA : Common Event Filters
BB:UBA : Authentication User or Group or Policy Changed
Not Used Tests: and when an event matches all of the following UBA : Common Event Filters, BB:UBA : Authentication User or Group or Policy Changed

Rule Name: UBA : Anomalous Account Created From New Location
Tests:
and when the event context is Local to Local, Remote to Local

and when BB:UBA : User Account Created match at least 1 times in 3 hour(s) after UBA : User Geography Change match with the same Username
Notes: Detects anomalous account creation activity from new location.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: UBA : Anomalous Account Created From New Location
UsingBB:
BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
BB:UBA : User Account Created match at least 1 times in 3 hour(s) after UBA : User Geography Change match with the same Username
EventContext:
Local to Local
Remote to Local
Not Used Tests:
and when the event context is Local to Local, Remote to Local
and when an event matches any of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and when BB:UBA : User Account Created match at least 1 times in 3 hour(s) after UBA : User Geography Change match with the same Username

Detects network Denial of Service (DoS) attacks by a user.

Before you enable the rule:
1. On the Admin tab, click UBA Settings, and then select the "Search assets for username, when username is not available for event or flow data" checkbox to search for user names in the asset table. The UBA app uses assets to look up a user for an IP address when no 2. Set up the "Snort Open Source IDS" log source.

Rule Name: UBA : Detect Insecure Or Non-Standard Protocol
Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and when the event matches Username is not any of [anonymous or unknown]
and NOT when any of Destination Port match N/A
and when an event matches any of the following BB:UBA : Insecure Ports
Notes: Detects any user communicating over unauthorized protocols which are regarded as insecure or non-standard protocols. BB:UBA : Insecure Ports excludes all UBA allowed ports and custom authorized protocols listed in the UBA : Ports of Authorized Protocols reference set. Edit the UBA : Ports of Authorized Protocols reference set with any other ports allowed in your environment before enabling this rule.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: UBA : Detect Insecure Or Non-Standard Protocol
UsingBB:
BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
BB:UBA : Insecure Ports
Not Used Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and when the event matches Username is not any of [anonymous or unknown]
and NOT when any of Destination Port match N/A
and when an event matches any of the following BB:UBA : Insecure Ports

Tests:
and when an event matches any of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and when none of BB:UBA : SSH Session Closed match in 10 hour(s) after BB:UBA : SSH Session Opened match with the same Username, Destination IP, Source IP, SSH Process ID (custom)
Notes: Detects SSH sessions that are active for more than 10 hours.
UsingBB:
BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
BB:UBA : SSH Session Closed match in 10 hour(s) after BB:UBA : SSH Session Opened match with the same Username
Not Used Tests:
and when an event matches any of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and when none of BB:UBA : SSH Session Closed match in 10 hour(s) after BB:UBA : SSH Session Opened match with the same Username, Destination IP, Source IP, SSH Process ID (custom)

Tests:
and when the event(s) were detected by one or more of Anomaly Detection Engine
and when any of Username are contained in any of UBA : User Accounts, Privileged, Observed - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
and when any of Event Name match UBA : User Has Gone Dormant (no activity anomaly rule)
Notes:
Please ensure that "UBA : User Has Gone Dormant (no activity anomaly rule)" is enabled to activate this rule.

Indicates that a username's activity count has changed by greater than 80%. "UBA : User Dormant Account Found (privileged)" and "UBA : User Has Gone Dormant (no activity anomaly rule)" are intended to point out when a user has stopped producing activity for an extended period. This condition could indicate that the user no longer requires access as indicated by a long absence of activity associated with their username.

False alarms are possible for if a Username's activity drops to zero during the short interval period (14 days by default) and before zero has become the new baseline (28 days by default). These will not affect a user's risk score if the response frequency limit for  "UBA : User Dormant Account Found (privileged)" is set to a period of time equal to or greater than the long interval per Username.
Username:
UBA : User Accounts
Privileged
Observed - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Not Used Tests:
and when the event(s) were detected by one or more of Anomaly Detection Engine
and when any of Username are contained in any of UBA : User Accounts, Privileged, Observed - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
and when any of Event Name match UBA : User Has Gone Dormant (no activity anomaly rule)

Tests:
and when an event matches any of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and when any of Username are contained in any of UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Dormant - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Notes:
Provides reporting functionality to indicate that a user successfully logged in after a dormant period.

The sensitivity of this rule, how soon it can fire after the user goes dormant, is governed by the time-to-live setting of "UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Recent".

Note : For best results, please wait 2 - 4 weeks before enabling both  "UBA : Dormant Account Used" and "UBA : Username to User Accounts, Successful, Dormant". This will allow the "UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Observed" and "UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Recent" reference sets to be populated and reduce the chances of prematurely triggering "UBA : Dormant Account Used".
UsingBB: BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
Username:
UBA : User Accounts
Successful
Dormant - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Not Used Tests:
and when an event matches any of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and when any of Username are contained in any of UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Dormant - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)

Rule Name: UBA : Executive Only Asset Accessed by Non-Executive User
Tests:
and when an event matches any of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success, BB:CategoryDefinition: Firewall or ACL Accept
and when an event matches all of the following UBA : Common Event Filters
and NOT when any of Username are contained in any of UBA : Executive Users - AlphaNumeric
and when any of Destination IP are contained in any of UBA : Executive Assets - IP
Notes:
Detects when a non-executive user logs on to an asset that is for executive use only.
Two empty reference sets will be imported with this rule : "UBA : Executive Users" and "UBA : Executive Assets". Edit the reference sets to add or remove any accounts and IP addresses that are flagged from your environment. Enable this rule after configuring the reference sets.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: UBA : Executive Only Asset Accessed by Non-Executive User

BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
BB:CategoryDefinition: Firewall or ACL Accept
EventMatches:

BB:CategoryDefinition: Firewall or ACL Accept
EventType:
BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
BB:CategoryDefinition: Firewall or ACL Accept
Not Used Tests:
and when an event matches any of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success, BB:CategoryDefinition: Firewall or ACL Accept
and when an event matches all of the following UBA : Common Event Filters
and NOT when any of Username are contained in any of UBA : Executive Users - AlphaNumeric
and when any of Destination IP are contained in any of UBA : Executive Assets - IP

with the same Username

Rule Name: UBA : Multiple Kerberos Authentication Failures from Same User
Tests:
and when an event matches any of the following BB:UBA : Kerberos Authentication Failures
and when BB:UBA : Kerberos Authentication Failures match at least 5 times with the same AccountName (custom) in 24 hour(s)
Notes:
Detects 5 or more Kerberos authentication ticket failures from the same user within 24 hours.

Note: The username for Kerberos is Account Name there is no username in the payload, so use custom property AccountName (custom) to match. Before using this rule, make sure you have enabled "Search assets for username, when username is not available on event or flow data" in the UBA Settings page. Or install Log Source Extension to parse AccountName as Username.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: UBA : Multiple Kerberos Authentication Failures from Same User
UsingBB:
BB:UBA : Kerberos Authentication Failures
BB:UBA : Kerberos Authentication Failures match at least 5 times with the same AccountName (custom) in 24 hour(s)
Not Used Tests:
and when an event matches any of the following BB:UBA : Kerberos Authentication Failures
and when BB:UBA : Kerberos Authentication Failures match at least 5 times with the same AccountName (custom) in 24 hour(s)

Rule Name: UBA : Network Traffic : Capture, Monitoring and Analysis Program Usage
Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following UBA : Common Event Filters
and when all of ObjectName_Filename (custom) are contained in any of UBA : Network Capture, Monitoring and Analysis Program Filenames - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Notes:
This rule indicates when a process is created and the process name matches one of the binary names listed in the reference set "UBA : Network Capture, Monitoring and Analysis Program Filenames". This reference set is a list of binary names of network packet capturing software. The reference set has been pre-populated with names of some common network protocol analysis software filenames.

Background:
   Packet capturing programs can allow a user to capture and examine traffic on a network. If these programs don't have adequate internal access controls, users may use them to learn information they might otherwise not have access to.

   In addition, these programs sometimes carry a risk of exploitation.

    IBM Trusted References :
        https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/search/tcpdump
        https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/search/netmon
        https://exchange.xforce.ibmcloud.com/search/wireshark

    Third Party References :
        http://sectools.org/tag/sniffers/?sort=release

Remedy :
    Examine the addresses and users involved. Ensure those systems are authorized to engage in packet capturing for administrative purposes.

    Refer to packet capture program's vendor documentation for patch, upgrade or suggested workaround information to mitigate any known vulnerabilities.

Detection notes and modification:
    The scope of this rule can be modified by adding or removing binary names for packet capturing tools to "UBA : Network Capture, Monitoring and Analysis Program Filenames"

    The reference set has been pre-populated with the following values:

        'wireshark.exe'
        'dumpcap.exe'
        'tshark.exe'
        'netmon.exe'
        'messageanalyzer.exe'
        'windump.exe'
        'nmap.exe'

    Example: To add detection for WinDump.exe, add the value 'windump.exe'  to the reference set 'UBA : Network Capture, Monitoring and Analysis Program Filenames' [Note - Do not include the quotes. For full details please see Qradar SIEM administration documentation topics 'Reference sets management' -and- 'Adding an element to a reference set' topics. ]

    The reference set "UBA : Network Capture, Monitoring and Analysis Program Filenames" is not case sensitive. 'netmon.exe' is equivalent to 'NetMon.exe'.

    The rule will not trigger if the Username is unavailable or any of the other "UBA : Common Event Filters" tests are true.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: UBA : Network Traffic : Capture Monitoring and Analysis Program Usage
Not Used Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following UBA : Common Event Filters
and when all of ObjectName_Filename (custom) are contained in any of UBA : Network Capture, Monitoring and Analysis Program Filenames - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)

Tests:

Username and different ObjectName (custom) in 1 minutes

Tests: and when UBA : Unauthorized Access match at least 7 times with the same Username in 5 minutes
Notes: Indicates that repeat unauthorized access activities were found.

Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following UBA : Common Event Filters
and when all of ObjectName_Filename (custom) are contained in any of UBA : Restricted Program Filenames - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Notes:
This rule indicates when a process is created and the process name matches one of the binary names listed in the reference set "UBA : Restricted Program Filenames". This reference set is for client customization and has been left blank by default. The suggested use of this rule and reference is that the client populates them with names of filenames which the client knows they'd like to monitor in the interests of risk management.

Detection notes and modification:
    The scope of this rule can be modified by adding and/or removing binary names for restricted tools to "UBA : Restricted Program Filenames"

    The reference set has been left blank by default.

    Example: To add detection for The Onion Router and The Onion Router browser executables, add the values 'tor.exe'  and ''Start Tor Browser.exe" to the reference set 'UBA : Restricted Program Filenames' [Note - Do not include the quotes. For full details please see Qradar SIEM administration documentation topics 'Reference sets management' -and- 'Adding an element to a reference set' topics. ]

    The reference set "UBA : Restricted Program Filenames" is not case sensitive. 'start tor browser.exe' is equivalent to 'Start Tor Browser.exe'.

    The rule will not trigger if the Username is unavailable or any of the other "UBA : Common Event Filters" tests are true.
Not Used Tests:
and when an event matches all of the following UBA : Common Event Filters
and when all of ObjectName_Filename (custom) are contained in any of UBA : Restricted Program Filenames - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)

Rule Name: UBA : Subject_CN and Username Map Update
Tests:
and when the event context is Local to Local, Remote to Local
and when an event matches any of the following UBA : BB : VPN Mapping (logic)
and when any of VPNsubject_CN (custom) are contained in any of UBA : VPN Subject_CN - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
and when any of VPNsubject_CN (custom) is the key and any of Username is the value in any of UBA : VPN Subject_CN and UserName - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Notes: This rule detects when a VPN event's Username is not equal to 'VPNSubjectcn'. This could indicate that there is VPN certificate sharing occurring. Certificate sharing or other authentication token sharing can make it difficult to identify who's done what. This can complicate taking next steps in the event of a compromise.
EventContext:
Local to Local
Remote to Local

Rule Name: UBA : TGT Ticket Used by Multiple Hosts
Tests:
and when an event matches any of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
and NOT when the source IP is one of the following 127.0.0.1
and when the event QID is one of the following (5000937) Success Audit: A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was granted
and when any of AccountName (custom) are contained in any of UBA : Kerberos Account Name - AlphaNumeric
and NOT when any of AccountName (custom) is the key and any of Source IP is the value in any of UBA : Kerberos Accounts and IPs - AlphaNumeric
Notes:
Detects Kerberos TGT ticket being used on two (or more) different computers

Note: The username for Kerberos is Account Name, there is no username in the payload, so use custom property AccountName (custom) to match User Account. Before using this rule, make sure you have enabled "Search assets for username, when username is not available on event or flow data" in the UBA Settings page, and rule "UBA : Kerberos Account Map". Or install proper log source extension.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: UBA : TGT Ticket Used by Multiple Hosts
UsingBB: BB:UBA : Common Event Filters
EventQIDDetails: (5000937) Success Audit: A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was granted
Not Used Tests:
and when an event matches any of the following BB:UBA : Common Event Filters

Notes: Detects any interactive session (through GUI and CLI, both local and remote login) that is initiated by a service or machine account in UNIX and Linux Servers. Accounts and allowed interactive sessions are listed in the UBA : Service, Machine Account and UBA : Allowed Interaction Session reference sets. Edit the reference sets to add or remove any interactive session that you want to flag from your environment.

UsingBB: BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Failures
EventType:
UBA : Common Event Filters
BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Failures

Local to Local
Remote to Local
Not Used Tests:

and when the event context is Local to Local, Remote to Local
and when an event matches all of the following UBA : Common Event Filters, BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Failures

Rule Name: UBA : User Access - First Access to Critical Assets
Tests:
and when any of Destination IP are contained in any of Critical Assets - IP
and when the event context is Local to Local, Remote to Local
and when an event matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success, UBA : Common Event Filters
and NOT when any of Destination IP is the key and any of Username is the value in any of Critical Systems Users Seen - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Notes: Indicates that this is a first-time access to a critical asset for this user. The "Critical Systems Users Seen" reference collection governs the time-to-live of an observation. By default this rule will detect the first access in three months.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: UBA : First Access to Critical Assets
UsingBB: BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
EventType:
BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success
UBA : Common Event Filters
EventContext:
Local to Local
Remote to Local

and when any of Destination IP are contained in any of Critical Assets - IP
and when the event context is Local to Local, Remote to Local
and when an event matches all of the following BB:CategoryDefinition: Authentication Success, UBA : Common Event Filters
and NOT when any of Destination IP is the key and any of Username is the value in any of Critical Systems Users Seen - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)

Rule Name: UBA : User Access Control Bypass Detected (Asset)
Tests:
and when the event(s) were detected by one or more of Microsoft Windows Security Event Log
and NOT when the event(s) were detected by one or more of UBA : Trusted Log Source Group
and when an event matches any of the following Detected a Fileless UAC Bypass using Fodhelper, Detected a Fileless UAC Bypass using sdclt, Detected a Fileless UAC Bypass using Windows Event Viewer, Possible UAC Bypass - A Scheduled Task Has Been Configured to Run With Highest Privileges
Notes: Detect process activities indicating User Access Control(UAC) bypass. Note this rule requires the 'Search assets for username, when username is not available for event or flow data' functionality to be enabled.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: UBA : User Access Control Bypass Detected (Asset)
EventMatches:
Detected a Fileless UAC Bypass using Fodhelper
Detected a Fileless UAC Bypass using sdclt
Detected a Fileless UAC Bypass using Windows Event Viewer
Possible UAC Bypass - A Scheduled Task Has Been Configured to Run With Highest Privileges
EventType:
Detected a Fileless UAC Bypass using Fodhelper
Detected a Fileless UAC Bypass using sdclt
Detected a Fileless UAC Bypass using Windows Event Viewer
Possible UAC Bypass - A Scheduled Task Has Been Configured to Run With Highest Privileges
Not Used Tests:
and when the event(s) were detected by one or more of Microsoft Windows Security Event Log
and NOT when the event(s) were detected by one or more of UBA : Trusted Log Source Group
and when an event matches any of the following Detected a Fileless UAC Bypass using Fodhelper, Detected a Fileless UAC Bypass using sdclt, Detected a Fileless UAC Bypass using Windows Event Viewer, Possible UAC Bypass - A Scheduled Task Has Been Configured to Run With Highest Privileges

Tests:
and when the event context is Local to Local, Remote to Local
and when an event matches all of the following UBA : Common Event Filters
and when Multiple Login Failures for Single Username match at least 1 times with the same Username in 15 minutes
Notes: Indicates a sequence of login failures to a local asset. Might  indicate account compromise or lateral movement activity. Ensure that the Multiple Login Failures for Single Username rule is enabled. Adjust this rule's match and time duration parameters to tune the responsiveness.
EventContext:
Local to Local
Remote to Local
Not Used Tests:
and when the event context is Local to Local, Remote to Local
and when an event matches all of the following UBA : Common Event Filters
and when Multiple Login Failures for Single Username match at least 1 times with the same Username in 15 minutes

Rule Name: UBA : User Has Gone Dormant (no activity anomaly rule)
Tests:
and when the average value (per interval) of Event Count (Sum) over the last 1 week is at least 80% different from the average value (per interval) of the same property over the last 2 weeks
and when the tested interval value is greater than or equal to 0
Notes:
Indicates that a username's activity count has changed by greater than 80%. This rule and it's dependent rule "UBA : User Dormant Account Found (privileged)" are intended to point out when a user has suddenly stopped producing activity.

           False alarms are possible for 'UBA : User Has Gone Dormant (no activity anomaly rule)' if a Username's activity drops to zero during the short interval period (14 days by default) and before zero has become the new baseline (28 days by default). These will not affect a user's risk score if the response frequency limit for  "UBA : User Dormant Account Found (privileged)" is set to a period of time equal to or greater than the long interval per Username.
RESP: Dispatch New Event Name: UBA : User Has Gone Dormant (no activity anomaly rule)

Notes:
Detects application installation events and then alerts when suspicious applications are seen.

Note: Populate the reference set "UBA : Authorized Applications" with the application names that are authorized in the organization.
The rule "UBA : Populate Authorized Applications" can be enabled for a short duration to populate this reference set.

Rule Name: UBA : Username to User Accounts, Successful, Dormant
Tests: and when an event matches any of the following UBA : Dormant User First Login (logic), UBA : Dormant User Subsequent Login (logic)
Notes:
Records the Username to "UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Dormant" when a successful user login is detected after a dormant period.

Note : For best results, please wait 2 - 4 weeks before enabling both  "UBA : Dormant Account Used" and "UBA : Username to User Accounts, Successful, Dormant". This will allow the "UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Observed" and "UBA : User Accounts, Successful, Recent" reference sets to be populated and reduce the chances of prematurely triggering "UBA : Dormant Account Used".
EventMatches:
UBA : Dormant User First Login (logic)
UBA : Dormant User Subsequent Login (logic)
EventType:
UBA : Dormant User First Login (logic)
UBA : Dormant User Subsequent Login (logic)
Not Used Tests: and when an event matches any of the following UBA : Dormant User First Login (logic), UBA : Dormant User Subsequent Login (logic)

UBA : Dormant User First Login (logic)

UBA : Dormant User Subsequent Login (logic)
Not Used Tests: and when an event matches any of the following UBA : User First Time Access (logic), UBA : Dormant User First Login (logic), UBA : Dormant User Subsequent Login (logic)

and when an event matches all of the following UBA : BB : VPN Mapping (logic)
and when any of VPNsubject_CN (custom) are contained in any of UBA : VPN Subject_CN - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
and NOT when any of VPNsubject_CN (custom) is the key and any of Username is the value in any of UBA : VPN Subject_CN and UserName - AlphaNumeric (Ignore Case)
Notes: This rule detects when a VPN event's Username is not equal to 'VPNSubjectcn'. This could indicate that there is VPN certificate sharing occurring. Certificate sharing or other authentication token sharing can make it difficult to identify who's done what. This can complicate taking next steps in the event of a compromise.

Tests:
and when the event(s) were detected by one or more of Microsoft Windows Security Event Log
and when any of EventID (custom) are contained in any of Hanzo - Windows Audit cleared - AlphaNumeric
Notes: This event record indicates that the audit log has been cleared. It is recorded even if auditing is turned off. The audit log should be saved in a file before deleting. The practice of always saving copies of audit logs is good for catching fraudulent users. A fraudulent user with sufficient privileges can delete the audit log as a way of erasing evidence of tampering with the computer systems and files. Lack of a backed-up audit log will help trace an unauthorized user. Once deleted, an audit log is lost unless a copy was made and saved before deleting.
EventIDDetails: Hanzo - Windows Audit cleared - AlphaNumeric
Not Used Tests:
and when the event(s) were detected by one or more of Microsoft Windows Security Event Log
and when any of EventID (custom) are contained in any of Hanzo - Windows Audit cleared - AlphaNumeric

Tests:
and when the event(s) were detected by one or more of Microsoft Windows Security Event Log
and when any of EventID (custom) are contained in any of Hanzo - Windows Audit Policy changes - AlphaNumeric
Notes:
This can be a result of Group Policy obtained from Active Directory or from Local Computer Policy that is configured on the computer. The details of the audit policy change are described in the event message.
This message does not necessarily indicate a problem. However, an attacker may change audit policy as part of a system attack. If successful, an attacker can disable auditing during their attacks and thereby destroy part of the evidence of the attack.
EventIDDetails: Hanzo - Windows Audit Policy changes - AlphaNumeric

Rule Name: Windows Logon Failure - Logon attempt failed for other reasons
Tests: and when an event matches any of the following BB: Hanzo: Windows 2003 Logon Failure - Logon attempt failed for other reasons, BB: Hanzo: Windows 2008 Logon Failure - Logon attempt failed for other reasons
Notes:
537: Logon failure - The logon attempt failed for other reasons.
0xC0000224,: user is required to change password at next logon 
0xC0000225: evidently a bug in Windows and not a risk
This event record indicates that a logon attempt was made and rejected for some reason other than those covered by explicit audit records in this category.
This problem occurs because Winlogon.exe incorrectly tries a cached logon process for the user who is logging on to the local computer.
